title: Coffee Shop Wait Times & 5-Number Summary
original_question: A student recorded waiting times (in minutes) for 15 customers: 2.5, 3.1, 4.0, 1.2, 5.5, 3.8, 4.2, 8.0, 2.9, 3.3, 4.1, 3.5, 3.0, 4.5, 2.8. The manager claims 'Most customers get coffee in under 4 minutes.' Provide the 5-number summary and evaluate the claim.

segments.explanation: Data must be sorted in ascending order to find the median and quartiles correctly.

segments.text: The manager claims 'Most customers get coffee in under 4 minutes.'
segments.highlight_text: Most customers get coffee in under 4 minutes
segments.explanation: In statistics, 'most' often refers to the majority; if the median is below 4, then at least 50% meet the criteria.

segments.text: Provide the 5-number summary and evaluate the claim.
segments.explanation: The summary includes Minimum, Q1, Median, Q3, and Maximum.

traps.title: Sorting Priority Error
traps.description: Attempting to identify the median or quartiles from the raw, unsorted list will result in incorrect values.

solution.step_desc: Sort the raw data in ascending order.
Evaluate the manager's claim based on the median.
solution.content: The median is 3.5 minutes, meaning 50% of customers wait 3.5 minutes or less. Furthermore, 10 out of 15 customers (67%) wait 4 minutes or less. The claim is supported.
solution.source_label: Most customers get coffee in under 4 minutes

title: Gasoline Octane Outlier Detection
original_question: An inspection of 20 gas samples yielded octane ratings: 87.1, 87.5, 88.0, 89.2, 90.1, 87.8, 88.5, 91.0, 87.2, 88.8, 89.5, 90.0, 88.2, 87.9, 88.4, 89.1, 90.5, 87.3, 88.7, 990.4. Use the 1.5*IQR rule to check if 990.4 is an outlier. If removed, what is the new Upper Whisker?

segments.explanation: A rating of 990.4 is significantly higher than other values and likely represents a recording error.

segments.text: Use the 1.5*IQR rule to check if 990.4 is an outlier.
segments.explanation: The rule defines outliers as values falling below $Q1 - 1.5 \times IQR$ or above $Q3 + 1.5 \times IQR$.

segments.text: If removed, what is the new Upper Whisker?
segments.explanation: The upper whisker is the largest data point that is NOT an outlier (stays within the upper fence).

traps.title: Whisker vs. Fence Confusion
traps.description: Students often incorrectly identify the calculated 'Upper Fence' value as the 'Upper Whisker'. The whisker must be an actual value from the dataset.

solution.content: Sorting the first 19 values gives Q1 = 87.85 and Q3 = 89.75. $IQR = 89.75 - 87.85 = 1.9$.

solution.step_desc: Determine the Upper Fence and test the suspected outlier.
solution.content: $Upper Fence = Q3 + (1.5 \times IQR) = 89.75 + (1.5 \times 1.9) = 92.6$. Since $990.4 > 92.6$, it is a confirmed outlier.

solution.step_desc: Identify the new Upper Whisker after removal.
solution.content: With 990.4 removed, the largest remaining value in the dataset that is less than the fence (92.6) is 91.0. Thus, the Upper Whisker = 91.0.
